abstract.para: The topic covers steps to take to verify that you will not break the system after switching to the enforcing mode.

topic.para: If you are peprforming configuration changes, it may be useful to switch to the permissive mode. During this time, users might label files incorrectly, and thus cause problem when switching back to the enforcing mode.
To return the system back to the secured state, perform the steps as follows:

step.para: Swotch to enforcing mode by setting the SELINUX=enforcing in the /etc/selinux/config.
Reboot the system and login again.
Run the sestatus -v command. It should give you an output similar to the following one:

&prompt.sudo;sestatus -v SELinux status: enabled SELinuxfs mount: /sys/fs/selinux SELinux root directory: /etc/selinux Loaded policy name: targeted Current mode: enforcing Mode from config file: enforcing Policy MLS status: enabled Policy deny_unknown status: allowed Memory protection checking: requested(insecure) Max kernel policy version: 33
